description: Jeff& I have going here for 18 yrs. Jeff on the handle has been going for over 30 yrs. We get the best service ever. The food is healthy. The owners are so sweet kind. Great service.
author: Karen B.

description: The restaurant I wanted to go to was closed but was still in the mood for sushi so I decided to drop by. Not busy during lunch time. Ordered a sushi combination plate with Philadelphia roll. I think the salmon nigiri from the combination was the best part. Fresh salmon that was fatty. I didn't like how the rice was coated with a little wasabi on the sushi and only found out when I noticed the rest of the sushi pieces had wasabi in it also. First time a restaurant has done that and I'm not a fan. I maybe the unpopular opinion here but I don't like anything that takes away the taste of sushi and that's wasabi. Some fruit flies were hovering near my table and a roach kept on running back to my table.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
This is a small no-frills place with maybe 8 tables and a small sushi bar. I was pleasantly surprised with the value and tastiness of a recent lunch I had here: the $9.95 lunch bento with tuna sashimi and shrimp/veg tempura. (There were various other combos at this price). The sashimi portion was on the small side but fresh and yummy. The tempura was hot and crispy and flavorful-unlike some places that serve theirs warm and flabby. I also appreciated the hot green tea that came with the meal.

Service was great-fast and courteous young server.
author: Trish W.

description:
I'm very satisfied with this restaurant! I rarely make a visit in this area because it's quite a ways from where I live but since San Tung was closed the day after Christmas, we decided to venture in to Micado as soon as we saw the big sign outside that said Teriyaki.

The restaurant is very homey feeling, it's not overly glitzed or glam but more of your traditional mom and pop's sit down restaurant with a mellow vibe. It doesn't scream hip but it's cozy and I liked that.

They have a selection of sushi and entrees but we decided on the chicken teriyaki because it's safe, and why not? It sounded like a great deal -- around $12 for a plate of chicken teriyaki, white rice, salad, and miso. They also served us tea free of charge and kept the refills coming!

When the chicken came out, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it came out piping hot on a sizzling platter! The chicken was so soft and moist, the teriyaki glaze was the perfect complement. The white rice was perfectly cooked, and the side salad was dressed with traditional japanese miso dressing.

I really enjoyed eating here, it's cozy and the food and ambiance is great!
author: Connie M.

description: I wanted to really try this place. We walked for late lunch...not very busy and looked okay at first glance. When we sat down and moved the specials menu little roaches crawled out. That convinced us to leave right away. Not sure about the quality of food but I wasn't really willing to risk it.
author: Elizabeth V.

description: I had the California roll($4.50) and New York roll($4.50). It was good and I liked eating all of it, so I guess I was happy. It doesn't take too much to make me like sushi rolls. I'll eat the ones from Safeway and Walgreen's haha. Nothing fancy here, but good Japanese food...oh and Saiwei Ramen was too crowded.
author: Denise C.

description: I would visit this place even if I did not live nearby. The family who runs it are most welcoming and sweet. The sushi is delicious particularly at this price point. Also, I absolutely love the seafood udon noodle. It has saved my life after happy hour drinks many many times. Try this place! That is all.
author: Anh H.

description:
I didn't realize I never wrote a review for this place. My husband and I have been coming here for at least 15 years. That's how long we've been married. Our daughter was born 9 months later. I'm getting somewhere with this! When our daughter was a baby, the lady owner would carry her so that we could eat. We never forgot it! Our daughter is 14 now and we still come here. 

They have the best chicken teriyaki. I don't get the sushi often, but when I have, it's good. Prices are decent. The lunch specials are great value too. 

This place is run by a Korean couple. Their adult son works there sometimes too. They are friendly and know their customers. It makes us want to support them. We've recommended this place to family as well.
author: Lani S.

description: Very pleased with my overall experience. My food order didn't take very long, the tea is okay. Really liked the quality of the fish and overall presentation.
author: Edgar C.

description: This is a GREAT spot for sushi.  Korean Family owned.  They obviously take pride in serving their customers. I had the "he- dop" which is a spicy salad served with rice and raw fish.  This is A favorite of mine and hard to find.  We also tried the sushi and found it to be fresh and wonderful.  Try the hand-rolled spicy tuna!  We will be back...
author: Stephen H.

description:
I used to live in Inner Sunset, where we also frequently ate at a Japanese restaurant in that neighborhood. So while I was in the Sunset area today,  I thought I'd have lunch at the same place. Driving down Irving, I passed by Micado and I thought,  hmmm, maybe I should  try this place.  It could save me time,  otherwise I'd have to drive down 18 more blocks.  So I gave it a try.  

Micado is a quick fix if you are in the mood for Japanese food.  But it's not authentic.  I ordered the bento box with shrimp tempura and tonkatsu. The moment my miso soup arrived,  I knew this was not Japanese owned because they served my soup with a spoon. I knew then not to expect much.  And I was right,  because the tempura dipping sauce was too salty, as well as the tonkatsu. 

Like I said,  it's a quick fix if you are in the mood for Japanese food.
author: Jake R.

description:
I've been going here for at least 12 years. Admittedly, I am not a sushi eater so sorry...

I always get the same thing...Beef teriyaki and tempura. It never fails. For the money, the best bento box in the city. And, there's never a wait!
author: Alan V.

description:
Rule number one: Always listen to Nobu K. If he says its jive ass its pretty much is.

This place is neither good nor bad. It is okay. The fish is okay not stellar. The rolls were unimpressive and not very flavorful.

I had originally wanted to go across the street to yumyum fish but after walking in I did not get the 4.5 stars...really funky place.

I think if you go here for the teriyaki, udon, tempura or donburi....I think you will be okay as those dishes look fine.
author: David G.

description:
Avocado roll are very yummy!
My parents and I love their avocado roll here!
The server, he is very nice and professional!
We all have a very pleasant lunch here!
author: Mary K.

description: Really amazing service. We walked in around 8 pm and got seated right away. The lady gave us free tea and kept refilling the whole time we ate. Had the salmon and chicken terriyaki dinner. The terriyaki sauce is so good definitely not watered down at all. Soup was good. And when I asked for a to go box the lady packed the food right in front of me! So nice and really fast service.
author: Alison S.

description: Very welcoming place. Got the lunch special from 11am-2:30 and was pleased. The chicken teriyaki was tender and tasty. Easy parking around.
author: Jose I.

description:
$12 for tempura udon??!

I felt ripped off ordering take out from them. So sad when I opened my container. My udon only consisted of noodles, bean cake and spinach with two thin shrimp tempura. I could have easily made it myself at home or buy the udon soup from Costco?

That's what I get for craving for udon.

So sad.
author: Carol Y.

description: Our favorite Japanese restaurant, especially for the awesome lunch specials! The owners are super friendly and treat me and my family like their own family. The food is always fresh and plentiful, a real jewel in our Central Sunset neighborhood!
author: Paul B.

description: Had dinner here last week. Maybe there was a reason the restaurant was pretty empty. The service was ok, but not so much on the food. My sushi was made ok (including the wasabi between the fish and the rice), but the pieces seemed hard, like they were made a while ago and refrigerated.
author: June W.

description:
"Why not give this place a shot", I thought as I walked by and saw the empty tables inside. As my party and I were seated, we looked over the menu. It had the usual bento boxes and rolls that you can find at any other Japanese restaurant. When trying to order the sukiyaki, we were told they were out, which would be fine, except that it seemed to have changed the mood of our server the rest of the meal. The service consisted of two visits to refill our tea and our check with an annoyed attitude, while she spent the rest of the meal sitting at the bar chatting with what seems to be other workers, paying no mind to our table. 

As for the food, a few comments. The tempura udon ($12) looks like a $3 meal, the caterpillar roll tasted like they used old avocado, and maybe this is a preference thing, but the chicken in the chicken teriyaki felt over boiled rather than grilled like other restaurants (the outer part was pretty mushy). Their portions were decent, enough to fill us up. But the quality and service at this restaurant was far from making it worth ~$20/person.
author: Ryan C.

description: My review is long overdue.  This restaurant is the best hole in the wall sushi place in the bay.  I used to live in the city, but now reside in Marin.  My bf and I make it a point to stop by Micado if we're ever in the area.  I rarely eat raw fish.  If I do, it needs to be the freshest fish in town as well as sushi grade.  They always have a great selection of sashimi.  The Ama Ebi and Hamachi Kama are my favorites and they have the best shrimp tempura in the bay! This restaurant has quality food at a very reasonable price.  Sushi man and his wife are always so welcoming, accommodating and funny! My mouth is watering as I'm writing this review.  Hmmm...we may just drive out to the city for dinner tonight
author: V R.

description: 49er roll is awesome! They put a little slice of lemon on it and it adds a unique gastronomic twist - a sour kick to the fatty, flavorful salmon
author: Morgan G.

description:
Just aimlessly driving around looking for a spontaneous lunch spot after a workout...

There's soooo many places to eat on Irving Street, but decided to go here for lunch. 

I have always drove by this place but never tried it out... 

Ordered the chicken teriyaki plate with rice and it was definitely A-OK.

Grill marks and everything but honestly felt like it was microwaved.

I've definitely had better, ugh!
author: Sam K.

description: Got a Tempura Udon for $9.95 for lunch, which came with 2 shrimp tempura on the side.  The Udon was a bit chewy and tasted fine.  The shrimp tempura tasted pretty fresh and crispy.  For the amount of food that you get, it wasn't really worth it since it wasn't really that filling.  If you decide to eat here, then I suggest you order a lot more than just an order of udon.  The lunch box special for $8.95 with a choice of 2 items would probably be a better bet.  I wouldn't order udon from here again and probably would try out the lunch box special instead.
author: Gilda W.

description:
Having tempura udan this time, not too bad I have to say. 
Will explore more some other day.
author: Kevin G.

description: Since Yum Yum across the street closed down I decided to try this place since they had a lunch special advertised. Two items for about $9. The food itself was salty, and the restaurant was empty. The owner/waitress was very rude. She never refilled my tea, didn't even say goodbye or welcome and I had to bring my credit card to her when I asked for the check since she didn't want to walk over to my table. With so many restaurants nearby I don't know how this one survived. Poor service and poor food, I won't be returning.
author: Jackie H.

description:
I have been going to Micado for 16 years and have never had a bad experience.  The owner and staff treat their customers like family and provide a warm and friendly atmosphere for lunch and dinner.

If you're going to a Japanese restaurant and complaining about having mediocre rolls and chicken teriyaki, news flash - you don't like sushi or Japanese food.  This is akin to complaining about Panda Express not having authentic Chinese food or Taco Bell not being a real Mexican restaurant.

Micado provides consistent, fresh nigiri and sashimi with a full compliment of Japanese appetizers and entrees.  The sushi rice is better here than any place in the Peninsula and most places I've tried in the City.  Texture, flavor, and temperature are on point, and the amount of pressure applied when assembling each piece of nigiri is excellent.  The balance of the wasabi and size of the slices of fish used for each piece shows the depth of sushi-making knowledge and consideration for the customer that the owner has.

Recommended starters are the fried soft-shelled crab and agedashi tofu.  These two are staples at most Japanese restaurants, but Micado does them better than most.  Lightly battered, meaty crab fried to crispy perfection provides a balance of sweet crab meat and savory innards, crunchy outside and firm, juicy inside.  The tofu is also lightly battered, served with house-made dipping sauce and bonito shavings, it is an awesome way to start a meal.

The sushi sashimi combination is my go-to meal, providing 5-6 slices of tuna sashimi, 6 pieces of California roll, and 10 pieces of nigiri.  This is the only place I enjoy eating a CA roll, because they use shredded crab meat instead of creamy imitation crab salad.

If you're feeling more American and want an entree instead of sushi, I would suggest the salmon teriyaki.  Served sizzling on a cast iron plate, it is skin-on, which protects the meat from burning while providing a delightfully crisp and fatty salmon skin treat.  Rice, salad, and miso soup are included, of course.

This place has been in business for as long as I've been alive, and I've been frequenting it for half that time, so far.  Even when I lived in San Jose for a decade, I would still come back home to eat here every other month or so, because the places I found in the South Bay just didn't offer the same quality of food or level of dining comfort.

Well worth the trip out to Irving on any night of the week!
author: Eric L.

description: never go here the lady is evil and she made us pay more she also tried to ignore us many times when we tried to order, all of us even waved at her crazily and she still avoided to make eye contact with us we saw our food at the sushi bar ready but she waited like 10 min later to give it to us never go here i repeat never go here i would give zero stars if i could
author: Alisha C.

description:
Empty restaurant. The bamboo design on the windows make more like a fence (so you can't see anything from the outside) and the closed door make this restaurant a little uninviting. Their banner outside with their popular lunch plates is what caught our attention - "chicken terriyaki." Yeah, that sounds good for dinner. The bf and I took a look at the menu which was posted on their window on the outside before entering. The sushi chef was sitting down watching the wheel of fortune. A lady greeted us and handed us menus. We initially thought we in a hurry so we ordered everything to-go. As we sat down to wait for our food, the waitress came back with two cups of hot genmai tea - I thought it was such a thoughtful gesture since we had ordered to go! But the tea was good. So perfect. We watched some wheel of fortune as we waited for our order. 

FOOD
-Katsu Donburi. Fried pork cutlet in scrambled eggs over rice. Hot and fresh off the stove served with salad and miso soup! Pretty standard, nothing to dislike. The eggs were a little sweet, I think that's normal though.The portion and price was fair ~$10. I took back leftovers. 
-Chicken Butteryaki. Tender chicken flavored with butter and lemon. Yummy. The bf ordered this but I think I should have instead. Also came with salad and miso soup. ~12.

SETTING
-Lots of tables, pretty spacious for Sunset.
-Empty for a Thursday night, so in otherwords, definitely not crowded. 
-They have a sushi bar! Didn't try the sushi though.
-One TV over the sushi bar. Something tells me that gameshows are usually on :)

Service was great and our food came out pretty quickly. I guess it helped that no one else came in while we were there. The waitress refilled our tea when we decided to stay and eat. It's your average Japanese restaurant (but is Korean owned). Nothing spectacular, but a decent and humble restaurant. If I were them I'd make the place seem a little more inviting so more passerbys would stop by.
author: Grace J.

description:
This place was really empty and quiet. The sushi chef looked miserable and looked like he didnt wanna be there. 

The sushi was so expensive. They put so much rice in the rolls. The radius of rice in the rolls was thicker than the little amount of fish in the rolls itself. No exaggeration.  

The green tea was so clear and diluted of water. The bowls of miso soup was filled up less than halfway. 

Service wasnt friendly. Im used to cordious japanese people.
author: Cuc N.

description: I love this place for what it is. Best sushi you'll ever have? No of course not. They do however make pretty damn good rolls and there lunch bento has been a staple of mine for years.
author: Nick O.

description: this is a no no. food was ok but service was terrible there was hair in one of my friends food and we think its the lady because all of our hair was too long and too short. by the way, the food took so long we took an hour here and this place is expensive but we literally paid 70 dollars when the check was 40 are you crazy
author: Ivan L.

description:
Most of the time, I try to consult Yelp before trying a new place. I just hate going in blind. I wish I had done so before coming here.. 

Micado is not cheap, nor is it super pricey. However, for the quality, portion size, and overall experience I felt like my money was put to waste.

I came with a friend. We both ordered the chirashi sushi, and gyoza + dragon roll to share. The gyoza came out first, and was actually not bad. Its hard to mess that up though. Then came the dragon roll.... I wish I had read the roll description before ordering, but wouldnt you expect a dragon roll to be, well, a dragon roll?! Their version only has shrimp tempura, wrapped with seaweed and rice, and topped with salmon and avocado. There is no crab, no unagi, no sauce, etc. I was shocked!!! The avocado on it was still yellow,  and it was $10.95 for such an unsatisfying 6 pieces.

Next came the chirashi.... it was one of the smallest I have ever had, and was around $15.95 if I remember correctly. Some of the fish was decent, but some of it was also obviously NOT fresh.

The prices are not terrible, but for what you get it feels like a rip off. I will not be back, and would not recommend anyone to come here.
author: Munnie T.

description: Extremely authentic spot with great food. Preparation is wonderfully done. The sushi is tasty. I have this spot bookmarked !
author: Bruce B.

description: My favorite place to eat Japanese food. People here are so nice and welcoming. Love their bento  box and soft shell
author: Den F.
